p: More than half of the world’s population is at risk of vector-borne diseases 1, causing public health concerns due to elevated mortality and high levels of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs) 2. Vector-borne diseases are currently a major problem in tropical developing countries 1. Climate variability influences vector population dynamics, distribution, and vector-borne disease transmission 3. Dengue transmission is associated in space and time with local climate effects on survival of its vector Aedes aegypti—more rain and higher temperature generates more transmission 4 5. Changes in inter-annual climate variability such as the El Niño Southern Oscillation have been shown to be important drivers for malaria transmission 6. Further, vectors also show distributional shifts from low to high altitudes during warm years 7.
